metadata.case_name: Panchshila Industrial Cooperative Society Multi Unit v. Gurgaon Central Cooperative Bank Ltd.

facts.text: The respondent Bank approached the Registrar of Cooperative Societies Haryana for resolving a dispute between the Bank and one of its members, the appellant.

The Registrar by his order dated February 17, 1968, in exercise of the powers vested in him under S. 56 of the Punjab Co-operative Societies Act, 1961, referred the dispute to the Deputy Registrar Cooperative Societies Rohtak for decision.

The arbitrator (Deputy Registrar of Cooperative Societies Rohtak) gave the award on October 7, 1969, directing that the appellant do pay to the respondent in all Rs. 16,05,658 - 20 together with interest at the rate of six and a half per cent per annum until the realisation of the principal amount viz. Rs. 11,52,535 00.
The appellant filed an appeal against this award before the Central Registrar of Cooperative Societies New Delhi (Appeal No. CR/1/70).
The Central Registrar dismissed the appeal by order dated May 4, 1970, holding that he was the appropriate appellate authority against the award.

The appellant was registered in December 1955 under the Punjab Cooperative Societies Act, 1955, and by virtue of the States Reorganisation Act, 1956, and S. 5A of the Multi-Unit Co-operative Societies Act, 1942, the appellant has become a multi-unit cooperative society.
The respondent Bank is a cooperative society governed by the provisions of the Punjab Co-operative Societies Act 1961.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Central Registrar was the appropriate authority on the facts of this case to hear the appeal against the award.

petitioner_arguments.text: The Central Registrar was not the appropriate appellate authority because the appellant has become a multi-unit cooperative society by virtue of the States Reorganisation Act, 1956, and S. 5A of the Multi-Unit Co-operative Societies Act, 1942, and has ceased to be governed by the provisions of the Punjab Co-operative Societies Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Multi-Unit Co-operative Societies Act, 1942 S.5A; States Reorganisation Act, 1956

petitioner_arguments.text: The Central Registrar should not have dismissed the appeal but returned the memorandum of appeal for presentation to the proper authority.

court_reasoning.text: The dispute between the respondent Bank and the appellant fell within S. 55 of the Punjab Co-operative Societies Act, 1961, and was properly referred to arbitration under that section.
court_reasoning.key_observation: There is no doubt that the dispute between the respondent Bank and the appellant fell within S. 55 and was properly referred to arbitration under that section.

court_reasoning.text: By virtue of the States Reorganisation Act, 1956, and S. 5A of the Multi-Unit Co-operative Societies Act, 1942, the appellant has become a multi-unit cooperative society but that Act has no impact on S. 55 of the Punjab Co-operative Societies Act, 1961, as the appellant remains a member of the respondent Bank, which is governed by the Punjab Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: There is nothing in the provisions of the Multi-Unit Co-operative Societies Act to indicate that a multi-unit cooperative society cannot be a member of a cooperative society governed by the Punjab Act of 1961.

court_reasoning.text: An appeal against the award lies under S. 68 of the Punjab Co-operative Societies Act, 1961, to the Government if the decision or order was made by the Registrar, and to the Registrar if made by any other person; thus, the Central Registrar had no jurisdiction to hear the appeal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: It is quite clear therefore, that the Central Registrar had no jurisdiction to hear the appeal.

court_reasoning.text: There is no statutory provision enabling the Central Registrar to return the appeal for presentation to the proper authority; if an appeal is filed before the appropriate authority under the Punjab Act, that authority will consider S. 14 of the Limitation Act, 1963 read with S. 29(2).
court_reasoning.key_observation: There is no statutory provision enabling the Central Registrar to do so.

holdings.text: The Central Registrar had no jurisdiction to hear the appeal against the award passed by the Deputy Registrar under the Punjab Co-operative Societies Act, 1961.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Co-operative Societies Act, 1961
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs disputes between member and society (S.55), reference to arbitration (S.56), and appeals (S.68); applies to the dispute and award.

statutes_cited.name: Multi-Unit Co-operative Societies Act, 1942
statutes_cited.relevance: Made appellant a multi-unit society but does not impact S.55 of Punjab Act as appellant remains member of respondent society.

statutes_cited.name: States Reorganisation Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Contributed to appellant becoming multi-unit cooperative society.

statutes_cited.name: Limitation Act, 1963
statutes_cited.relevance: Appropriate authority may consider for excluding time spent pursuing appeal before wrong forum.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Cooperative Societies Act, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Appellant originally registered under this Act.

outcome.summary: The appeal by special leave against the order of the Central Registrar dismissing the appeal against the arbitrator's award is dismissed, confirming that the Central Registrar lacked jurisdiction; appropriate authority under Punjab Act may consider Limitation Act provisions if appeal refiled.

key_quotes.text: The only question which arises before us is whether the Central Registrar was the appropriate authority on the facts of this case.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: States the sole issue for decision.

key_quotes.text: It is quite clear therefore, that the Central Registrar had no jurisdiction to hear the appeal.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: In the result the appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.
key_quotes.speaker: court
